But it displeased Jonah exceedingly, and he was very angry.

And he prayed unto the LORD, and said, I pray thee, O LORD, <FI>was<Fi> not this my saying, when I was yet in my country? Therefore I fled before unto Tarshish: for I knew that thou <FI>art<Fi> a gracious God, and merciful, slow to anger, and of great kindness, and repentest thee of the evil.
Therefore now, O LORD, take, I beseech thee, my life from me; for <FI>it is<Fi> better for me to die than to live.
Then said the LORD, Doest thou well to be angry?<RF>Doest…: or, Art thou greatly angry?<Rf><CM>
So Jonah went out of the city, and sat on the east side of the city, and there made him a booth, and sat under it in the shadow, till he might see what would become of the city.

And the LORD God prepared a gourd, and made <FI>it<Fi> to come up over Jonah, that it might be a shadow over his head, to deliver him from his grief. So Jonah was exceeding glad of the gourd.<RF>gourd: or, palmcrist: Heb. Kikajon<Rf><RF>was…: Heb. rejoiced with great joy<Rf>
But God prepared a worm when the morning rose the next day, and it smote the gourd that it withered.

And it came to pass, when the sun did arise, that God prepared a vehement east wind; and the sun beat upon the head of Jonah, that he fainted, and wished in himself to die, and said, <FI>It is<Fi> better for me to die than to live.<RF>vehement: or, silent<Rf>

And God said to Jonah, Doest thou well to be angry for the gourd? And he said, I do well to be angry, <FI>even<Fi> unto death.<RF>Doest…: or, Art thou greatly angry?<Rf><RF>I do well…: or, I am greatly angry<Rf>

Then said the LORD, Thou hast had pity on the gourd, for the which thou hast not laboured, neither madest it grow; which came up in a night, and perished in a night:<RF>had pity: or, spared<Rf><RF>came…: Heb. was the son of the night<Rf>
And should not I spare Nineveh, that great city, wherein are more than sixscore thousand persons that cannot discern between their right hand and their left hand; and <FI>also<Fi> much cattle?<CM>
